text:
David Cameron speech in full after Brexit Share this video Watch Next 
Berwick Conservative MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan also backed the Leave campaign. 
David Cameron agreed a “deal” with other EU nations in February, including some very limited restrictions on benefits that EU migrants could claim. 
The referendum campaign got under way properly with confirmation that a vote would be held on June 23 - and Mr Cameron suffered a major blow when high-profile London mayor Boris Johnson came out in favour of quitting. 
We heard a series of horror stories about the potential impact on the North East of Brexit. The region’s universities would lose funding and firms such as Nissan might stop investing, we were told. 
But Mr Johnson visited the North East in April, where he said: “EU membership costs the North East half a billion pounds every single year.” 
Campaigning briefly halted after Yorkshire MP Jo Cox was murdered in her constituency in June. Prime Minister David Cameron speaks outside 10 Downing Street, London (Photo: Lauren Hurley/PA Wire) 
David Cameron had always been confident of winning the EU referendum. He would never have held the vote if he thought he might lose. 
But as the results came in, in the early hours of June 24, it was soon clear he’d miscalculated. 
Newcastle was the first council in the country to declare. And it was a win for Remain, but not by much, with 65,404 people in the city voting to stay in the EU and 63,598 voting to Leave. 
Remain campaigners had expected a bigger margin of victory than that. 
At 4am that morning, the BBC announced that although counting continued in some parts of the country, it was clear the Leave campaign had won. 
David Cameron announced later that same morning that he was resigning as Conservative leader and Prime Minister. 
Meanwhile, Labour politicians were furious with their leader, Jeremy Corbyn, claiming he’d campaigned only half-heartedly to stay in the EU. Labour 
Labour was a divided party throughout 2016, although the in-fighting reduced significantly after Jeremy Corbyn was elected leader for a second time in September. 
There was an early sign of things to come when North Durham MP Kevan Jones resigned as a Shadow Defence Minister in January, saying he wanted to be free to make the case for the renewal of the Trident nuclear weapons system. 
Later that same month, Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell resigned as Shadow Attorney General. She cited a desire to spend more time with her family but also accused Mr Corbyn of taking the party down “an increasingly negative path”. The Durham Miners Gala takes place in Durham City Centre. Colliery banners are paraded to the Durham Cricket Club green where Jeremy Corbyn address the crowds who support his campaign 
But the announcement that Mr Corbyn had accepted an invitation to attend the Durham Miners’ Gala illustrated why his supporters back him. 
He was the first Labour leader to attend the gala for four years, after his predecessor, Ed Miliband, turned up in 2012. Tony Blair and Gordon Brown never made it at all. 
There was an ongoing row over claims of anti-Semitism within the party. Newcastle MP Chi Onwurah said in April that Labour does not have a “widespread problem” with anti-Semitism but said the party must confront the small number of anti-Semites in its ranks. 
But the divisions came to a head after the EU referendum. 
A series of Labour MPs resigned from the party’s front bench. They included City of Durham MP Roberta Blackman-Woods , who quit her post as a Shadow Local Government Minister, and Washington and Sunderland West MP Sharon Hodgson, who resigned her post as Shadow Minister for Children and Families. 
Labour MPs voted for a motion saying they had no confidence in their leader. Angela Eagle 
And former Shadow Business Secretary Angela Eagle prepared to launch a leadership challenge - before colleagues decided they’d prefer Labour MP Owen Smith to take on Mr Corbyn instead. 
Mr Corbyn was backed by North East MPs such as Blyth Valley MP Ronnie Campbell and Easington MP Grahame Morris. 
When the votes were counted in September, Mr Corbyn was the clear winner. 
It meant a promotion for Newcastle East MP Nick Brown, who returned to the top level of politics as the new opposition chief whip. 
However, opposition to Mr Corbyn continues. 
Len McCluskey, leader of trade union Unite and an ally of Mr Corbyn, announced in December that he would resign, triggering a leadership contest in 2017 when he will stand again. Labour “moderates” hope they will succeed in replacing him. Conservatives Boris Johnson and Theresa May 
The Conservatives got their leadership contest out of the way quickly following David Cameron’s resignation decision. 
Boris Johnson, seen by many as the favourite, announced he wasn’t standing after all. 
His former friend, Michael Gove, ruined what chances he had when he attacked Mr Johnson in what was seen as an act of disloyalty. 
Former Energy Minister Andrea Leadsom quit the contest after she was criticised, perhaps a little unfairly, for appearing to make a comment about Theresa May having no children. 
It meant Mrs May, the former Home Secretary, was the only candidate in the race - and she was duly crowned party leader and Prime Minister. 
She quickly stamped her mark on the party, promising at the Conservative conference in October to take on business fat cats and to get tough on immigration. 
The populist approach was her response to the mood of the country revealed, as she saw it, in the EU referendum result. Green Party Natalie Bennett, Leader of the Green Party 
The Green Party set out plans for an economically self-reliant North as leader Natalie Bennett visited the proposed site of the Druridge Bay coal mine in Northumberland in January 
She said she would invest in Northern manufacturing to ensure that the region was less dependent on London, and would improve links between large Northern cities. 
Green MP Caroline Lucas and Jonathan Bartley took over as the party’s joint leaders in September. The economy Generic image of the 'living wage' which is £7.65 (Photo: Rob Browne) 
The economy of the North East is booming in many respects - but the region also continued to suffer extreme poverty. 
Businesses in the North East were revealed as the UK leaders when it comes to exporting to China and India, Government figures showed in January. 
The Government’s living wage, effectively a 50p increase in the minimum wage for people aged 25 and over, came into effect in April. 
A quarter of Northumberland employees received a pay rise, the Government said. Good news, although it partly reflects the number of people on low wages to start with. 
But the region continued to have the worst unemployment level in the country throughout the year. 
And North East MPs highlighted the challenges facing the region in a series of Commons speeches. 
Labour Durham MP Roberta Blackman-Woods said people in the Northern Powerhouse were “now facing a choice between food or a roof over their head”. 
It came after figures from charity Shelter showed that 1.8 million people across the North will struggle to heat their home and pay their rent or mortgage this month. 
But it wasn’t only Labour that expressed concern about people struggling to get by. 
Conservative Anne-Marie Trevelyan, MP for Berwick-upon-Tweed, warned that cuts to housing benefit known as the bedroom tax had left some Northumberland families without a suitable home. 
And the Bishop of Durham spoke out against poverty, and led the House of Lords in defeating Government plans to scrap child poverty targets. 
Members of the Lords backed his proposal to force Ministers to present a report to Parliament each year setting out the percentage of households in low income households. Devolution
